articles.headline: M.L.B. Pulls All-Star Game From Georgia in Response to Voting Law
articles.snippet: The move served as a warning to Republicans in other states who are trying to restrict voting, and is likely to put new pressure on other organizations and corporations to consider pulling business out of Georgia.
articles.abstract: The move served as a warning to Republicans in other states who are trying to restrict voting, and is likely to put new pressure on other organizations and corporations to consider pulling business out of Georgia.
articles.lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball sent a warning shot on Friday to Republicans considering new laws to restrict voting, pulling its summer All-Star game out of suburban Atlanta in a rebuke to Georgia’s new election rules that will make it harder to vote in the state’s urban areas.
articles.byline: By Kevin Draper, James Wagner, Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: ‘Totally Unnecessary’: Veteran Police Officer Rebukes Derek Chauvin’s Conduct
articles.snippet: The longest-serving officer on the Minneapolis police force said Mr. Chauvin had violated department policy when he knelt on George Floyd for more than nine minutes.
articles.abstract: The longest-serving officer on the Minneapolis police force said Mr. Chauvin had violated department policy when he knelt on George Floyd for more than nine minutes.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The police officer had seen hundreds of crime scenes, interviewed scores of witnesses and made his share of arrests over more than 35 years working cases in Minneapolis.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

articles.headline: Driver Rams Into Officers at Capitol, Killing One and Injuring Another
articles.snippet: The attack shocked a Capitol slowly returning to normalcy after the Jan. 6 riot, raising new questions about securing the complex.
articles.abstract: The attack shocked a Capitol slowly returning to normalcy after the Jan. 6 riot, raising new questions about securing the complex.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The band of razor wire-topped fencing around the Capitol had recently come down. The heavy National Guard presence had begun to thin.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane, Nicholas Fandos and Ben Decker

articles.headline: We Have All Hit a Wall
articles.snippet: Confronting late-stage pandemic burnout, with everything from edibles to Exodus.
articles.abstract: Confronting late-stage pandemic burnout, with everything from edibles to Exodus.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like many of us, the writer Susan Orlean is having a hard time concentrating these days. “Good morning to everyone,” she tweeted recently, “but especially to the sentence I just rewrote for the tenth time.”

articles.headline: ‘I Was Failing’: Bystanders Carry Guilt From Watching George Floyd Die
articles.snippet: Their pain has been mostly hidden for the last 10 months. But over the first week of Derek Chauvin’s murder trial, it spilled tearfully into the open as witnesses testified to their shared trauma.
articles.abstract: Their pain has been mostly hidden for the last 10 months. But over the first week of Derek Chauvin’s murder trial, it spilled tearfully into the open as witnesses testified to their shared trauma.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Alyssa Funari needed a cord to connect her cellphone to the car to play music, so she pulled up to a corner store in South Minneapolis one early evening last May.

articles.headline: How Trump Steered Supporters Into Unwitting Donations
articles.snippet: Online donors were guided into weekly recurring contributions. Demands for refunds spiked. Complaints to banks and credit card companies soared. But the money helped keep Donald Trump’s struggling campaign afloat.
articles.abstract: Online donors were guided into weekly recurring contributions. Demands for refunds spiked. Complaints to banks and credit card companies soared. But the money helped keep Donald Trump’s struggling campaign afloat.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stacy Blatt was in hospice care last September listening to Rush Limbaugh’s dire warnings about how badly Donald J. Trump’s campaign needed money when he went online and chipped in everything he could: $500.

articles.headline: He Built a $10 Billion Investment Firm. It Fell Apart in Days.
articles.snippet: Banks were eager to do business with Bill Hwang and his Archegos Capital Management — until he ran out of money.
articles.abstract: Banks were eager to do business with Bill Hwang and his Archegos Capital Management — until he ran out of money.
articles.lead_paragraph: Until recently, Bill Hwang sat atop one of the biggest — and perhaps least known — fortunes on Wall Street. Then his luck ran out.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly, Matthew Goldstein, Matt Phillips and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: ‘She Just Fell Down. And She Died.’
articles.snippet: Myanmar’s security forces have killed more than 40 children since February. Here is the story of one, Aye Myat Thu. She was 10.
articles.abstract: Myanmar’s security forces have killed more than 40 children since February. Here is the story of one, Aye Myat Thu. She was 10.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the swelter of the hot season, U Soe Oo cracked open the coconut with practiced blows of his machete. Small hands reached out for the first slice, cool and slippery.

articles.headline: Amid Awakening, Asian-Americans Are Still Taking Shape as a Political Force
articles.snippet: Divided by generation, ethnicity and class, but currently galvanized by a surge of racially motivated attacks, Asian-Americans are growing rapidly as political players.
articles.abstract: Divided by generation, ethnicity and class, but currently galvanized by a surge of racially motivated attacks, Asian-Americans are growing rapidly as political players.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Minority Entrepreneurs Struggled to Get Small-Business Relief Loans
articles.snippet: A year after the Paycheck Protection Program started, studies show how its design hurt Black- and other minority-owned businesses.
articles.abstract: A year after the Paycheck Protection Program started, studies show how its design hurt Black- and other minority-owned businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Southern Bancorp is a lender serving the Arkansas and Mississippi Delta, where poverty rates are among the highest in America and decades of redlining shaped neighborhoods with little generational wealth.

articles.headline: A Car Crash in the California Desert: How 13 Died Riding in One S.U.V.
articles.snippet: In one of the deadliest border-related crashes in decades, many who died illustrate a new dynamic on the border: more migrants from Mexico.
articles.abstract: In one of the deadliest border-related crashes in decades, many who died illustrate a new dynamic on the border: more migrants from Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLTVILLE, Calif. — The maroon Ford Expedition was so heavy its wheels spun at first in the soft desert sand as it cleared a breach in the border wall. It then sped down a dirt road as Mexico disappeared in the rearview mirror. Twenty-five people held on inside, many jammed on the floor, others hunched half-standing between them.
articles.byline: By Miriam Jordan and Ariana Drehsler

articles.headline: Biden Effort to Combat Hunger Marks ‘a Profound Change’
articles.snippet: As millions of Americans lack enough to eat, the administration is rapidly increasing aid — with an eye toward a permanent safety net expansion.
articles.abstract: As millions of Americans lack enough to eat, the administration is rapidly increasing aid — with an eye toward a permanent safety net expansion.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With more than one in 10 households reporting that they lack enough to eat, the Biden administration is accelerating a vast campaign of hunger relief that will temporarily increase assistance by tens of billions of dollars and set the stage for what officials envision as lasting expansions of aid.

articles.headline: Divided Kingdom: Jordan Shaken by Split Between King and Ex-Crown Prince
articles.snippet: A royal rift laid bare. Key figures arrested. Rumors of a failed coup attempt. An intense bout of palace intrigue has knocked Jordan’s image as a reliable bulwark in a turbulent part of the world.
articles.abstract: A royal rift laid bare. Key figures arrested. Rumors of a failed coup attempt. An intense bout of palace intrigue has knocked Jordan’s image as a reliable bulwark in a turbulent part of the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — The kingdom of Jordan has long been considered an oasis of relative stability in the Middle East. While wars and insurgencies flared in neighboring Syria and Iraq, Jordan was for decades considered a secure and dependable ally of the United States, a buffer against attacks on Israel, and a key interlocutor with Palestinians.
articles.byline: By Rana F. Sweis, Adam Rasgon and Patrick Kingsley

articles.headline: The Lawyer Behind the Throne at Fox
articles.snippet: Even before the company’s C.E.O., Lachlan Murdoch, moved to Australia, Viet Dinh was seen as Fox’s power center.
articles.abstract: Even before the company’s C.E.O., Lachlan Murdoch, moved to Australia, Viet Dinh was seen as Fox’s power center.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In early 2019, as the Murdoch family completed the $71 billion sale of 21st Century Fox to Disney, executives at the movie studio learned that someone was reading all their emails.

articles.headline: White Evangelical Resistance Is Obstacle in Vaccination Effort
articles.snippet: Millions of white evangelical adults in the U.S. do not intend to get vaccinated against Covid-19. Tenets of faith and mistrust of science play a role; so does politics.
articles.abstract: Millions of white evangelical adults in the U.S. do not intend to get vaccinated against Covid-19. Tenets of faith and mistrust of science play a role; so does politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stephanie Nana, an evangelical Christian in Edmond, Okla., refused to get a Covid-19 vaccine because she believed it contained “aborted cell tissue.”
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Dias and Ruth Graham

articles.headline: Inside Corporate America’s Frantic Response to the Georgia Voting Law
articles.snippet: Companies like Delta are caught between Democrats focused on social justice and populist Republicans. They face major political consequences no matter what they do.
articles.abstract: Companies like Delta are caught between Democrats focused on social justice and populist Republicans. They face major political consequences no matter what they do.
articles.lead_paragraph: On March 11, Delta Air Lines dedicated a building at its Atlanta headquarters to Andrew Young, the civil rights leader and former mayor. At the ceremony, Mr. Young spoke of the restrictive voting rights bill that Republicans were rushing through the Georgia state legislature. Then, after the speeches, Mr. Young’s daughter, Andrea, a prominent activist herself, cornered Delta’s chief executive, Ed Bastian.

articles.headline: Amazon’s Clashes With Labor: Days of Conflict and Control
articles.snippet: Amazon was built on an underdog philosophy, but its workers are finding a voice. That presents a problem for the company that goes far beyond the union vote in Alabama.
articles.abstract: Amazon was built on an underdog philosophy, but its workers are finding a voice. That presents a problem for the company that goes far beyond the union vote in Alabama.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been Day 1 at Amazon ever since the company began more than a quarter-century ago. Day 1 is Amazon shorthand for staying hungry, making bold decisions and never forgetting about the customer. This start-up mentality — underdogs against the world — has been extremely good for Amazon’s shoppers and shareholders.

articles.headline: Tribune Publishing Considers New Offer From Surprise Bidders
articles.snippet: Two months after agreeing to sell itself to the hedge fund Alden Global Capital, the company behind The Chicago Tribune and The Baltimore Sun may shift course.
articles.abstract: Two months after agreeing to sell itself to the hedge fund Alden Global Capital, the company behind The Chicago Tribune and The Baltimore Sun may shift course.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tribune Publishing, the newspaper chain that includes The Chicago Tribune, The Daily News and The Baltimore Sun, said on Monday that it had begun serious discussions about a sale of the company to a pair of bidders who came through with an offer nearly two months after it agreed to sell itself to Alden Global Capital, a New York hedge fund.
